questions.text: A healthcare provider is assessing a postpartum mother with a viral infection for breastfeeding suitability. Given the mother's diagnosis, the provider must decide if breastfeeding should be contraindicated. Which viral infection in the mother commonly requires temporary cessation of breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes Simplex

 

Option C:

 

Herpes Simplex virus (HSV) presents a risk if the mother has active herpes lesions, particularly on the breasts. If there is an active HSV lesion on the breast, breastfeeding from the affected side should be stopped until the lesion has resolved to prevent transmission to the infant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hepatitis B is not a contraindication for breastfeeding as long as the infant receives the appropriate vaccinations.

 

Option B: Hepatitis C is generally not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding. Transmission through breast milk is not common, and breastfeeding may continue unless there is nipple bleeding.

 

Option D: Varicella Zoster, responsible for chickenpox, is not a contraindication for breastfeeding if the mother has immunity before pregnancy or if the baby has received varicella zoster immune globulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While most maternal viral infections do not prohibit breastfeeding, certain conditions like active herpes simplex lesions on the breasts can necessitate temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding on the affected side to prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A 35-week-gestation infant, born to a mother with poorly controlled pregestational diabetes (insulin-dependent with vascular disease, HbA1C 9%), is delivered via cesarean section due to fetal macrosomia and distress. Neonate is at risk for several complications due to the maternal diabetes and premature birth. In addition to birth asphyxia, cardiac septal hypertrophy, and polycythemia, which of the following conditions is this infant at an increased risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

 

Option C: 

 

Infants born to mothers with poorly controlled diabetes are at risk for respiratory distress syndrome (surfactant deficiency) at later gestational ages than seen in infants born to mothers who do not have diabetes.

 

Infants of diabetic mothers are also at increased risk of the following complications:

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome
  • Macrosomia
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Polycythemia
  • Prematurity

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congenital dislocated hip is not specifically associated with maternal diabetes or prematurity but is related to factors like breech presentation and family history.

 

Option B: Dacryostenosis, or the obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, is a common condition in newborns but is not directly linked to maternal diabetes or prematurity.

 

Option D: Hyperglycemia is less common in infants of diabetic mothers immediately postpartum. These infants are typically at risk for hypoglycemia due to their own increased insulin production in response to maternal hyperglycemia before birth.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hyaline membrane disease, also known as neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, is more common in preterm infants due to insufficient surfactant production. Infants of diabetic mothers, especially those with poor glycemic control, are at an increased risk for this condition, as maternal hyperglycemia can delay fetal lung maturity. The high levels of insulin in these infants, a response to maternal hyperglycemia, can further inhibit surfactant production, exacerbating the risk of respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 3997

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

 

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain activity, including the brainstem. It is a clinical diagnosis based on the absence of neurological function and the irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness and spontaneous respiration.

 

In brain death, the following clinical observations can be present and may be mistakenly interpreted as signs of brainstem function, but they do not indicate any meaningful brain activity:

 

Things That Can Be Present in Brain Death- 

  1. Normal blood pressure without drugs
  2. Spinal reflexes
    1. Movements like Babinski, deep tendon reflexes may be seen.
    2. These come from the spinal cord, not the brain
  3. Sweating or tachycardia
    1. Autonomic responses — do not indicate brain activity.
  4. What is Not Seen in Brain Death:
    1. Decorticate or decerebrate posturing
      1. These need some brain activity
      2. In brain death: no such posturing happens — total motor silence.


         

 

However, decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not seen in brain death. These postures are indicative of severe brain injury but require some level of brain activity to generate the motor response. In brain death, all brain-originating motor responses, including these postures, are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal BP without pharmacological support: Autonomic responses may still maintain blood pressure without brain function, making this observation consistent with brain death.

 

Option B. Positive spinal reflexes on stimulation: These reflexes are mediated by the spinal cord, not the brain, and thus can still occur in brain death.

 

Option C. Sweating and tachycardia: These autonomic functions can persist despite brain death due to residual autonomic nervous system activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain death is characterized by the complete absence of brain-originating motor responses, including decorticate and decerebrate posturing, despite possible preservation of autonomic functions like normal BP and spinal reflexes.

questions.text: A concerned father brings his 8-year-old son, Dev, to the pediatric clinic after noticing his frequent complaints of bone pain and a recent incident where a minor fall resulted in a fracture. During the examination, the pediatrician observes multiple healing fractures of varying ages on the X-rays, along with noticeable bruises on the skin. Initially, there is a suspicion of non-accidental injury, but further assessment reveals Dev has a short stature, distinctive blue sclera, and visible bone deformities in his limbs and spine. These findings suggest a genetic condition affecting bone strength rather than external trauma. What is the pattern of inheritance for Dev's diagnosed condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autosomal Dominant

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis based on the David’s history is Osteogenesis imperfecta and it is Autosomal Dominant in nature.

 

The clinical features include

  • Multiple fractures: recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma. Can cause deformities or shortening of limbs.
  • Blue sclera: Its due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities.
  • Dental problems: Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly. (Dentinogenesis imperfecta - The bluish, opalescent sheen on several teeth results from genetically defective dentin).
  • Hearing loss: Hearing loss occurs in approximately 20% of young children and as many as 50% of adults by the age of 50
  • Skeletal deformities: scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest).
  • Short stature: due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth.
  • Easy bruising: Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of frequent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclera, short stature, and bone deformities, strongly suggests Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). OI is a genetic disorder primarily affecting collagen, leading to brittle bones and a susceptibility to fractures. The majority of OI cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, meaning a single copy of the defective gene from either parent can cause the disorder.

Note - Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) (brittle bone disease) is the most common genetic cause of osteoporosis.

 

Ref: nelson 21st Edition – Page No-14415-14427

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with viral myositis. Viral myositis is an inflammation of the muscles caused by viral infection, often following an upper respiratory tract illness. The condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Recent viral illness: The history of fever and cough 3 days prior suggests a preceding viral infection, which is a common trigger for viral myositis.
  • Leg pain and muscle tenderness: Viral myositis often presents with significant muscle soreness, especially in the calf muscles, leading to pain on palpation.
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels: The CK level of 2000 IU indicates muscle injury or inflammation, which is consistent with viral myositis.
  • Normal reflexes and neurological examination: This helps differentiate viral myositis from other conditions like Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) or Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which would typically present with abnormal reflexes or progressive muscle weakness.

 

Influenza is a common viral cause of myositis, particularly in children. The muscle pain typically begins 1-7 days after the onset of the viral illness and may lead to difficulty walking, often with a characteristic toe-walking gait due to involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, typically presenting with proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, and elevated CK levels. However, it does not present acutely following a viral illness and usually starts earlier in life.

 

Option C. GBS (Guillain-Barré Syndrome): GBS is an autoimmune condition that causes ascending paralysis, starting with weakness in the legs. Reflexes are usually diminished or absent in GBS, unlike the normal reflexes observed in this case.

 

Option D. Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It usually presents with chronic, progressive weakness rather than acute pain following a viral illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?  ? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

choices.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic
Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia
Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life
If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about congenital CMV infection? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

 

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a significant cause of congenital infection and can lead to a range of outcomes in the fetus, depending on the timing and nature of maternal infection. If a mother is IgG positive for CMV, it indicates a past infection and a lower risk of transmitting the virus to the fetus compared to a primary infection. This is because maternal IgG antibodies can provide some protection to the fetus. However, there remains a small risk of reactivation of the virus or reinfection during pregnancy, which could lead to congenital CMV infection in the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic is incorrect because the correct percentage of symptomatic congenital CMV infections at birth is about 10%, not 20-30%.

 

Option B. Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia: Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia is incorrect because enamel hypoplasia is not a typical part of the triad for congenital CMV infection. The common findings include SNHL, periventricular calcifications, and developmental delays.

 

Option C. Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life: Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life is incorrect because asymptomatic infants at birth are less likely to develop hearing loss, and if they do, it is usually sensorineural, not conductive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal IgG positivity for CMV suggests a lower risk of congenital CMV transmission, making it less likely for the fetus to develop the infection.

questions.text: On the initial day of treatment for a child diagnosed with Severe Acute Malnutrition, the attending physician calculates the dose of folic acid to administer. What is the standard initial dosage of folic acid for a child on the first day of SAM management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The recommended initial dose of folic acid in the management of SAM is 5 mg on the first day and then 1 mg every day till day 14 of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of SAM - Micronutrients supplementation

 

  • Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals.

  • On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU)

  • Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1)

  • Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day

  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day

  • Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome: partial deletion of short arm of Chr 5, leads to cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.
  • Bloom syndrome: rare autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer and genomic instability.
  • Angelman syndrome: caused by deletion in maternal chromosome 15 or paternal uniparental disomy, affects nervous system, delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.
  • Fragile X syndrome: genetic disorder, also known as Martin-Bell syndrome, most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: features are:

 

  • Short stature
  • Sun sensitive rash over the nose and nose and cheeks
  • Immune deficiency 
  • Insulin resistance that resembles Type 2 Diabetes

 

The question doesn’t mention such feature. Therefore, bloom syndrome is not the right answer

 

Option C. Angelman syndrome: remember “angel is the mother” therefore, in this syndrome maternal gene is deleted. It is one of the examples of uniparental disomy. The clinical features are:

 

 

  1. Maternal gene is deleted
  2. Paternal gene is doubled
  3. Dev delay
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Microcephaly
  6. Hyperactive
  7. Spontaneous laughter - Happy Puppets
  8. Hypertonia
  9. UBE3A GENE ON Chr 15 is defective/absent

 

Option D. fragile x syndrome: it is the second most common non preventable cause of mental retardation. The features are:

 

  1. Male patient
  2. Large ears
  3. Large testes
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Nose will NOT be large

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 12%

 

A day-night variation of FEV1 > 12%, is not a standard measure used in the diagnosis of asthma. While diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (PEF) is often used to monitor asthma control, it is not specifically measured by FEV1, and a >12% variation in FEV1 between day and night is not typically used as a diagnostic criterion for asthma.

 

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are essential in diagnosing and managing asthma, particularly in identifying airflow obstruction and its reversibility. Specific findings on PFTs suggestive of asthma include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation: An increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) by more than 15% after the administration of a bronchodilator like salbutamol is indicative of reversible airway obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

 

Option B. FEV1/FVC< 80%: A FEV1/FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) ratio of less than 80% is suggestive of obstructive lung disease, including asthma. This ratio decreases because of the increased airway resistance in asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Decrease in FEV1>12% after exercise: A decrease in FEV1 by more than 15% after exercise is a sign of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a common feature of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in FEV1 > 12% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: During a routine neonatal examination, a nurse assesses a newborn's overall well-being using the apgar score, a quick and standardized evaluation performed at one and five minutes after birth. Considering the components of the apgar score, which of the following is not a factor included in this assessment tool?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Respiratory rate 

 

The Apgar score evaluates five key parameters of a newborn's well-being:

 

  1. Heart rate: Heart rate is one of the five key components of the Apgar score and is assessed using a stethoscope or palpation.
  2. Respiratory effort (not respiratory rate)
  3. Muscle tone: This refers to Motor activity, another parameter of the Apgar score, which evaluates the infant's active movements and flexion.
  4. Reflex irritability (response to stimulation)
  5. Skin color:  Skin color is an important Apgar parameter that assesses the newborn for cyanosis or pallor, indicating oxygenation.

 

Respiratory effort, not respiratory rate, is assessed in the Apgar score. This parameter evaluates the strength and quality of the baby's breathing, such as crying or other respiratory efforts, rather than a specific numerical count of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Transposition of Great Arteries.
Endocardial Cushion defects
Pentalogy of Fallot
Coarctation of Aorta

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in by their mother, who is distressed due to criticism from her mother-in-law regarding the child's health. The child has developmental delays, intellectual disability, and distinctive physical features including sandal gap toes. Recently, the child has been diagnosed with a congenital heart disease. Given the child's clinical features, as shown in the images, what is the most common congenital heart disease associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endocardial Cushion defects

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of the child is pointing towards the diagnosis of Downs Syndrome. The most common congenital heart disease in case of Downs syndrome is Endocardial Cushion defects (AVSD)

 

The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are.

Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye.

  • Short neck
  • Abnormally shaped ears
  • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand.
    • Brachycephaly
    • Protrudin  g tongue
    • Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option A, C and D aren’t the most common congenital heart disease in Downs Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Downs syndrome - Approximately 40% children have congenital heart disease. Endocardial cushion defects account for about 40-60% cases. Presence of heart disease is the most significant factor in determining survival. All children should have a cardiac evaluation before 9 months of age, including echocardiography.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 610-615.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Based on the clinical presentation of low hemoglobin levels, the presence of target cells in the blood smear, and the need for repeated blood transfusions, the most likely diagnosis is thalassemia. Thalassemia is an inherited disorder affecting the production of alpha- or beta-globin chains, leading to an imbalance in globin chain synthesis. This imbalance results in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, requiring frequent blood transfusions.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A genetic disorder that can be categorized into alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia based on the affected globin chain. The severity of the condition depends on the number of functioning globin genes.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive diagnosis of thalassemia is made through globin gene sequencing, which identifies mutations in the genes encoding the globin chains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): HPLC is used as a screening tool for thalassemia and other hemoglobinopathies by analyzing hemoglobin fractions. However, it is not definitive for diagnosing thalassemia.

 

Option B. Ferritin levels estimation: Ferritin levels are used to assess iron stores in the body, particularly in cases of iron deficiency anemia or iron overload. It is not diagnostic for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: While bone marrow aspiration can reveal ineffective erythropoiesis and hypercellularity, it is not used for a definitive diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Hemoglobin Patterns:

 

  • Normal Hemoglobin Pattern: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is another tool used for screening, often complemented by HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

 

On the fourth day, this child's bilirubin level is only 8 mg/dl, indicating physiologic jaundice. Because the child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding on a regular and exclusive basis.

 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is caused by increased bilirubin production from foetal red blood cell breakdown combined with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation by the immature neonatal liver.

 

It usually appears on the second or third day after birth, peaks on the fourth day at 5-6 mg/dL, and then drops to 2 mg/dL between the fifth and seventh days.

 

Note: Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

 

  1. Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth.
  2. Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant.
  3. Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level.
  4. Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) levels above the expected normal range -Jaundice is seen in the mid-abdomen (= 15 mg/dL) and soles (- 20 mg/dL).
  5. Total Serum Bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy.
  6. Total Serum Bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exchange transfusion: exchange transfusion is not the correct option.

 

Indications of exchange transfusion are:

 

  1. History of Direct coombs test positive
  2. Cord hemoglobin < 5gm/cl and cord bilirubin >10 mg /dl
  3. History of sibling death / erythroblastosis fetalis

 

Option B. Stop breastfeeding and start phototherapy: We don’t stop breast feeding unless the baby is a case of galactosemia or lactose intolerance because in these conditions breast feeding is contraindicated.

 

Option C. IV fluids and phototherapy: IV fluids is not the right option as the baby is feeding well. We don’t give IV fluids to a baby who is feeding well.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

The most likely diagnosis for the case presented is atopic dermatitis, a common inflammatory skin condition often associated with the atopic state, which includes eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. This condition is characterized by impaired epidermal barrier function, often due to a genetic predisposition. In many patients, a mutation in the filaggrin gene is responsible for this barrier defect.

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with:

 

  • Eczematous lesions: These lesions are often red, inflamed, and may ooze or become crusted. They frequently occur in flexural areas such as the elbows, knees, and neck.
  • Pruritus (itching): Intense itching is a hallmark of atopic dermatitis, often leading to scratching that can exacerbate the lesions.
  • Chronic course: The condition usually has a chronic course with periods of exacerbation and remission. Lesions often persist for more than 6 weeks.
  • Family history: There is often a personal or family history of atopic conditions, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, or food allergies.
  • Lichenification: Chronic scratching may lead to thickened, leathery skin, known as lichenification.

 

The clinical image provided shows red, excoriated lesions in the flexure aspect of the elbow, which is highly characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically presents with flaccid blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, not with the eczematous lesions seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, thick, silvery scales on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees. It is not associated with the flexural distribution or the intense pruritus seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option C. Post-traumatic pigmentation: This refers to skin discoloration following an injury. It does not present with eczematous lesions or intense itching, and it is not limited to flexural areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

questions.text:
What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder
  2. lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby
  3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby
  4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4


According to the Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines, the recommended actions for a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid are as follows:

 

4. For a non-vigorous baby (poor muscle tone, weak or absent respiratory effort, or heart rate <100 bpm): The baby should receive positive pressure ventilation (PPV) following initial resuscitation steps. The current guidelines recommend PPV over routine intratracheal suctioning in non-vigorous infants because studies have shown that routine suctioning does not improve outcomes and may delay necessary resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction of the nose and mouth before delivery of the shoulders and routine intratracheal suctioning are no longer recommended in the current guidelines.

 

Option B. 2, 4: While PPV is recommended for non-vigorous infants, routine intratracheal suctioning is not indicated.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction is not recommended under the current guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is a crucial tool used in neonatal screening for detecting inborn errors of metabolism. This test involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel, which is then dried on a filter paper and sent for analysis. Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the primary technique used to analyze the sample for a wide range of metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU), maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), and others. Early detection through DBS testing allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment, significantly improving the prognosis for affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood grouping: Blood grouping in neonates is typically done in cases of suspected neonatal jaundice to rule out Rh or ABO incompatibility, not using DBS testing.

 

Option C. Bilirubin testing: Bilirubin levels are tested to evaluate jaundice in neonates, particularly in cases of Rh or ABO incompatibility or breastfeeding-related jaundice, but this is not done using DBS.

 

Option D. Coombs Test: The Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that may cause hemolysis in conditions like hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is not performed using dried blood spots.

 

Educational Objective:


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

choices.text: Less than 500 grams; facilitating prompt respiratory support
Less than 750 grams; guiding nutritional interventions
Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies
Less than 1,500 grams; indicating the need for developmental follow-up

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a premature infant is born with a birth weight of 850 grams. To categorize the degree of prematurity and guide appropriate medical interventions, the healthcare team refers to the extremely low birth weight (elbw) cutoff. What is the generally accepted elbw cutoff?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

 

Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW) refers to infants with a birth weight of less than 1,000 grams (1 kg). These neonates are at significant risk of complications due to their underdeveloped organs and systems, requiring intensive medical care.

 

Medical interventions for ELBW infants focus on:

 

  • Respiratory support: ELBW infants are often born with underdeveloped lungs, requiring mechanical ventilation or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
  • Nutritional support: Parenteral nutrition is crucial, transitioning to enteral feeds as tolerated.
  • Temperature regulation: ELBW infants have immature skin and poor fat stores, making thermoregulation a critical part of their care.
  • Developmental monitoring: These infants are at risk for long-term neurodevelopmental impairments and require close follow-up.

 

The ELBW cutoff helps guide the intensity of medical and supportive care required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Less than 500 grams: While infants under 500 grams are categorized as "micro-preemies," this is not the accepted ELBW cutoff.

Option B. Less than 750 grams: While this category includes many ELBW infants, the standard definition is less than 1,000 grams.

 

Option D. Less than 1,500 grams: Infants in this weight range fall under the Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW) category, which is distinct from ELBW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW) is defined as a birth weight of less than 1,000 grams. These infants require specialized care due to their high risk of complications.

questions.text: A mother brings her 17-month-old child to the doctor for routine eye checkup. On examination the Doctor notices a thinned-out cornea. On asking history, the child has a history of iron deficiency anemia. The weight of the child is 10kg, what should be the dose of vitamin A to be given in this child of based on the age?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 2,00,000 IU

questions.text: A concerned mother visits your clinic with her 3-year-old child, worried about the child's inadequate growth. The child's medical history reveals a low birth weight, along with ongoing feeding difficulties and a poor appetite. Upon physical examination, you note several distinctive features: a prominent forehead, a small jaw, a narrow chin, and clinodactyly. These clinical findings, combined with the child's growth issues, lead you to consider a specific diagnosis. Based on the information provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Russell - Silver syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Russell-Silver Syndrome

 

Most cases occur sporadically, chromosome 11p15, maternal disomy of chromosome 7.

Possible risks include:

 

  • Metabolic syndrome.

  • Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis

  • Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males.

  • Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density.

  • Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uniparental disomy (UPD) is when a child gets both copies of a chromosome from one parent. This can lead to conditions like Prader-Willi syndrome (if both chromosome 15s come from the mother) and Angelman syndrome.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1696, 2987

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

 

In the management of severe COVID-19 in children, corticosteroids are the primary treatment among the given options. Corticosteroids are recommended for children with severe cases, which include conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe pneumonia, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).

 

Severe COVID-19 is characterized by symptoms such as SpO2 less than 90% on room air, severe chest retractions, grunting, lethargy, and signs of pneumonia with cyanosis. In these cases, corticosteroids like Dexamethasone or Methylprednisolone are used to reduce inflammation and manage the severe immune response associated with the virus.

 

Guidelines for Steroid Use in Severe COVID-19:

 

  • Indications: Corticosteroids are indicated in rapidly progressive moderate cases and all severe cases. They are generally avoided in the first 3-5 days of illness due to the risk of increased viral shedding during this period.
  • Dosage: Dexamethasone is given at a dose of 0.15 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 6 mg once a day, or Methylprednisolone at 0.75 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 30 mg once a day.
  • Duration: The treatment typically continues for 5-6 days and then is tapered off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is not recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children. Ivermectin has been used for deworming, not for treating COVID-19.

 

Option C. Remdesivir: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication used in some hospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 but is not the primary treatment for severe cases in children. It inhibits viral replication by terminating RNA transcription prematurely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.
