questions.text:
Identify the following instruments which are used for the measurement of the nutritional status of the child?

 

 

1. Harpenden caliper

2. Salters Scale

3. Shakir’s Tape

4. Infantometer
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A3 B4 C2 D1

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tape Measure: Used for measuring mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), which is an important anthropometric measurement of nutritional status, particularly in identifying malnutrition in children.

 

Option B. Infantometer: This device is used to measure the length or height of infants and small children. It is essential for assessing linear growth and determining stunting.

 

Option C. Spring Scale: Often used for weighing infants and young children. The child is usually placed in a sling which is then attached to the scale.

 

Option D. Skinfold Caliper: Utilized to measure skinfold thickness at various body sites to estimate body fat percentage, a key component in evaluating nutritional status.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 1842

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

It is true that bowel and bladder dysfunction increase the incidence of recurrence of UTI in children, and that children who experience a recurrence of UTI undergo a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

 

The classical presentation is described as the 6 P's of congenital hypothyroidism: pot-belly, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development and persistent opening of posterior fontanelle, prolong jaundice & hypotonia.

 

The given laboratory finding of increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level in an 8-day-old baby is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Radiotracer uptake with technetium will be the next investigation in this condition to confirm the presence of the thyroid gland.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine iodine excretion: This test measures the iodine content in urine and is typically used to assess iodine deficiency in populations rather than diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in an individual.

 

Option B. Serum thyroid receptor antibody: This test is more relevant in diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease rather than congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Perchlorate secretion test: This test is used to identify a defect in thyroid hormone synthesis, particularly in conditions like thyroid dyshormonogenesis, but it is not the first-line investigation for a neonate with high TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: During a routine OPD session on Holi, a police officer brings in an unidentified child for age verification. To determine the child's age, you order a wrist X-ray. Upon reviewing the X-ray, you identify the age of the child to be approximately 2 months. Which of the following carpal bones did you primarily rely on to estimate the age of the child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Capitate

 

Option B.

 

The fist carpel bone to ossify is the capitate which is within the first 3 months of life.

The sequence of ossification of carpal bones, as shows in the image –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scaphoid will ossify by 4-6 years of age.

 

Option C. Lunate will ossify by 2-4 years of age

 

Option D. Trapezoid will ossify by 4-6 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Although there is great individual variability, approximate ossification times are as follows:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1127

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21%


During neonatal resuscitation, the initial amount of oxygen administered to a term baby is 21%, which corresponds to the concentration of oxygen in room air. The rationale behind starting with 21% oxygen is to avoid the potential risks associated with high concentrations of oxygen, such as oxidative stress and damage to the delicate tissues of a newborn, particularly the lungs and eyes.

 

Bag and mask ventilation using an AMBU (Artificial Manual Breathing Unit) bag, also known as a self-inflating bag, is the standard method used during neonatal resuscitation. The oxygen concentration delivered can vary depending on the setup:

 

  • AMBU without reservoir and without oxygen inlet: Provides 21% oxygen, as it uses room air.
  • AMBU with a reservoir and with oxygen inlet: Can deliver close to 100% oxygen.
  • AMBU with a reservoir but without an oxygen inlet: Delivers approximately 40% oxygen.

 

Given the guidelines and the need to balance adequate oxygenation with minimizing the risks of hyperoxia, resuscitation of a term newborn typically begins with 21% oxygen, with adjustments made based on the infant’s response and ongoing clinical assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 50%: Starting with 50% oxygen is not standard practice for neonatal resuscitation, as the recommendation is to start with room air (21%) and adjust as necessary.

 

Option C. 100%: High concentrations of oxygen, such as 100%, are avoided initially due to the risks of oxygen toxicity and oxidative stress, which can cause harm to the newborn, particularly to the eyes (risk of retinopathy of prematurity) and lungs.

 

Option D. 75%: Similar to 50% and 100%, 75% oxygen is not recommended as the starting concentration for neonatal resuscitation in term babies.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

 

By the age of 24 months (2 years), most children develop the ability to use a spoon and feed themselves, which is a key fine motor skill. By the age of 3 years, this skill is typically well established, allowing the child to handle a spoon with greater proficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one foot: Hopping on one foot is a motor milestone that typically develops around the age of 4 years. Skipping usually comes later, around 5 years.

 

Option C. Copying a triangle: The ability to copy shapes such as a triangle is generally seen around 5 years of age. More complex shapes like a diamond are usually copied around 7 years of age.

 

Option D. Repeats sentences of 10 syllables: A child's ability to repeat longer sentences, including those with 10 syllables, generally develops around 4 to 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:


By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a concerned mother presents her infant, worried about the child's weight gain. She compares her baby to her sister-in-law's seemingly healthier child. Upon examination, the infant appears active and alert. The mother reports that the birth weight was 2600 grams, and currently, the scale reads 5300 grams, indicating that the infant's weight has doubled. As an intern, you recall the standard growth milestones and reassure the mother. Based on standard pediatric growth patterns, at what age is an infant's weight expected to double from birth?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 5 months

 

Option D.

 

Weight of an infant doubles by 5-6 months and quadruples by 2 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The weight of the baby triples by 1 year of age and doubles by 5 months.

 

Option B. The weight of the baby becomes 4 times the birth weight by 2 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months.

 

Option C. The weight of the baby becomes 5 times the birth weight by 3 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: ↑ bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: ↑ conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by their mother, who is concerned about the child's noticeably shorter stature compared to peers. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the child's short stature appears disproportionate, with a more significant discrepancy between the upper and lower body segments. Considering a potential diagnosis of a condition affecting growth, the pediatrician decides to assess the child's body proportions more closely by measuring the upper segment and lower segment ratios. Understanding the normal progression of body proportions from childhood to adulthood is crucial in this assessment. At what age do the upper and lower segments of the body typically reach adult proportions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 10 years

 

Option D:

 

Upper segment lower segment ratio:

Upper segment — vertex to pubic symphysis

Lower segment — pubic symphysis to heel

 

Normal Values

Birth—1.7:1

3 years—1.3:1

7 years - 1:1

In adults the ratio is: 0.9:1

So, the best answer according to the options is D

 

Explanation:

 

Option A- By the age of 2 years the ratio is 1.4:1

 

Option C- By the age of 7 years the ratio is 1:1 whereas the adult ratio is 0.9:1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper-to-lower body segment ratio (U/L ratio) provides an assessment of truncal growth relative to limb growth. The lower-body segment is defined as the length from the top of the symphysis pubis to the floor, and the upper-body segment is the total height minus the lower-body segment.

The U/L ratio equals approximately 1.7 at birth, 1.3 at 3 year, and 1.0 after 7 year. Higher U/L ratios are characteristic of short-limb dwarfism, as occurs with Turner syndrome or bone disorders, whereas lower ratios suggest hypogonadism or Marfan syndrome.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51; Nelson 21st Ed Pg 1183

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

 

Dehydration in children is classified based on clinical signs into mild (some dehydration) and severe dehydration. The symptoms of severe dehydration are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and urgency of care.

 

"Thirsty child," is typically associated with some dehydration rather than severe dehydration. A thirsty child is likely still alert and responsive, seeking fluids, which suggests that dehydration is present but not yet severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drowsy child: Indicates severe dehydration where the child’s mental status is altered, often due to inadequate perfusion to the brain.

 

Option B. Skin pinch retracts slowly: This is a reliable sign of severe dehydration and indicates significant fluid loss.

 

Option D. Sunken fontanelle: Especially in infants, a sunken fontanelle is a common and concerning sign of severe dehydration, indicating decreased intracranial pressure due to fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text:
A medical student is rotating in the neonatal intensive care unit and is being quizzed on the identification and purpose of various neonatal care devices. The attending physician shows the student four images labeled A, B, C, and D, each depicting a different device. The student is asked to match the following devices with their corresponding names:

 

 

  1. Radiant Warmer
  2. Phototherapy unit
  3. Bilirubinometer
  4. Incubator
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A2 B1 C4 D3

 

Option C: 

 

 

Explanation:

 

A2 - Phototherapy Unit: Image A shows a neonate under a blue light, characteristic of a phototherapy unit used for treating hyperbilirubinemia in newborns by converting bilirubin into more soluble forms through structural isomerization.

 

B1 - Radiant Warmer: Image B depicts a device used to maintain the body temperature of neonates by providing radiant heat. This is important for premature infants or those who cannot regulate their temperature.

 

C4 - Incubator: Image C illustrates an enclosed apparatus designed to provide a controlled and protective environment for premature or ill newborns, which is indicative of an incubator.

 

D3 - Bilirubinometer: Image D shows a handheld device being used on a neonate's forehead, which is typically a non-invasive bilirubinometer used to measure bilirubin levels in newborns.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 2190

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Step-by-Step Calculation

 

Step 1: Identify the appropriate k value

For a 4-year-old child: k = 0.413

 

Step 2: Apply the formula

eGFR = k × Height / Serum Creatinine

 

Step 3: Substitute values

eGFR = 0.413 × 100 / 1

 

Step 4: Calculate

eGFR = 41.3 / 1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73 m²

 

Step 5: Round to nearest option

41.3 ≈ 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.

 

The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:

 

 

 

For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413

 

Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:

 

 

 

The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer

 

Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lethargy

 

Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration. In the context of dehydration, it is important to differentiate between signs that indicate mild to moderate (some) dehydration and those that suggest severe dehydration. Lethargy indicates a more serious state of fluid loss that affects the child's overall responsiveness and energy levels, which is not characteristic of mild or moderate dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: This sign can occur in both some and severe dehydration. When the skin, typically on the abdomen or arm, is pinched and it returns to its original position slowly, it indicates decreased skin turgor, a common sign of dehydration.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: Sunken eyes can be a symptom of both some and severe dehydration. It is a visible sign that reflects reduced fluid in the body, causing the eyes to appear sunken.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because one of the choices (lethargy) is not a sign of some dehydration but rather severe dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:


Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is “ boot shape heart “

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: A 25-year-old mother named Mala delivered her first child at a primary health care center. The delivery was noted to be complicated, with the neonate having a delayed cry and subsequent development of neurological signs. The medical officer observed signs consistent with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) and promptly referred the newborn to a higher-level facility for further evaluation and management. Upon examination at the referral center, the neonate exhibited hypotonia, exaggerated ankle reflexes, recurrent focal seizures, and miotic pupils. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely stage of HIE according to the Sarnat and Sarnat staging system?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2

 

Option B: 

 

Based on the clinical findings of hypotonia, exaggerated ankle reflex and recurrent focal seizures, which are typically seen in case of Stage 2 of HIE.

 

HIE - Refers to CNS dysfunction or encephalopathy associated with Perinatal asphyxia.

Potential to cause mortality and long term sequelae like disabilities and cerebral palsy.

 

Etiology: Pathologically, any factors which interfere with the circulation between maternal and fetal blood exchange.

 

Pathophysiology of Asphyxia

 

Redistribution of blood flow to vital organs (brain, heart and adrenal) to prevent hypoxic damage. ‘Diving Reflex’

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stage 1 (Mild HIE): This stage is characterized by hyperalertness, jitteriness, increased muscle tone, irritable and exaggerated reflexes, without significant alterations in level of consciousness or seizures.

 

Option C: Stage 3 (Severe HIE): Neonates in this stage present with stupor or coma, flaccid muscle tone, absent reflexes, and often have severe autonomic dysfunction.

 

Option D: Stage 4 is not classed under Sarnat and Sarnat staging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 12509

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath and fainting episode. On further evaluation features of short stature and webbed neck were noted. He was subjected to cardiological examination where he is diagnosed with pulmonary stenosis. A genetic testing was done in which chromosome 12 is found to be abnormal. On compiling all the history and clinical features he is diagnosed as a case of pseudo turner syndrome known as Noonan Syndrome. What is the gene responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTPN 11 gene

 

Option B.

 

PTPN 11 gene in chromosome 12 is responsible for Noonan Syndrome

 

Clinical features include;

  • Short stature
  • webbed neck
  • Anti-mongoloid Slant of eyes.

Most common cardiac anomaly associated is Pulmonary stenosis 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CLCN 7 gene mutation will results in osteopetrosis, a condition characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone growth.

 

Option C. CFTR gene mutation will result in Cystic Fibrosis, affecting the lungs, pancreas, and other organs.

 

Option D. ATM gene mutation will results in Ataxia Telangiectasia, rare inherited childhood neurological disorder that affects the part of the brain that controls motor movement (intended movement of muscles) and speech. The triad of symptoms includes progressive ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasias and sinopulmonary disease. 

 

Educational objective:

 

Turner Syndrome vs Noonan Syndrome

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 601– Page No 11714-11716

questions.text: A Medical Officer in a Regional healthcare center is addressing concerns of a mother who is worried about her milk supply being inadequate for her infant's needs. The MO assures her that breast milk composition typically provides all necessary nutrients in the right amounts. To demonstrate this point, she quizzes the interns present, about the sodium content of breast milk. What is the sodium content in breast milk measured in mEq/L?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 mEq/L

 

Explanation:

 

Breast milk has a relatively low sodium content compared to other fluids, which is appropriate for the kidney's filtering capacity of an infant. On average, breast milk contains 7 mEq/L of sodium, which meets the infant's nutritional requirements without overloading their renal system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

  • Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is a condition that arises from excessive alcohol exposure during pregnancy, which leads to a range of developmental abnormalities. FAS is characterized by several key features, including facial anomalies, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction, and growth deficiencies.

 

  • Facial Anomalies: The classic facial features of FAS include small eye openings (narrow palpebral fissures), a smooth philtrum (the area between the nose and upper lip), and a thin upper lip. Other features may include epicanthic folds, a flattened nasal bridge, a short nose, low-set and unparallel ears, and midfacial hypoplasia.
  • CNS Dysfunction: This includes microcephaly (small head size), mental retardation, and neurobehavioral abnormalities such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The presence of microcephaly is a common finding in FAS, reflecting the overall poor brain growth and development.
  • Thinning of Corpus Callosum: FAS can lead to structural brain abnormalities such as thinning or complete agenesis of the corpus callosum, which is the band of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Holoprosencephaly: This is a severe brain malformation where the forebrain fails to divide into two hemispheres, which can be seen in more severe cases of FAS.

 

Macrocephaly (enlarged head size) is not a feature of FAS. On the contrary, FAS is typically associated with microcephaly, reflecting the impaired brain growth caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a known CNS abnormality in FAS, reflecting the significant impact of alcohol on brain structure and development.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: One of the hallmark features of FAS, microcephaly indicates reduced brain size and development, commonly seen in affected infants.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: This severe brain malformation can occur in the context of FAS, particularly in cases where the alcohol exposure has profoundly disrupted early brain development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: During rounds with your consultant, several cases of genetic diso rders in the pediatric ward were discussed. Your consultant asks about the most common chromosomal disorder, its complication, and its associated disorders. Match the following columns correctly to demonstrate your understanding and facilitate further discussion:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A2 B3 C4 D1

 

Explanation:

 

 

Some important points

 

  • Nondisjunction - Common aneuploidies seen in live born babies include Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edward syndrome (trisomy 18), Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Turner syndrome (monosomy X).

  • Chromosome deletion - William syndrome (7qll.23); retinoblastoma with mental retardation and dysmorphic facies (13q14.1); Prader-Willi syndrome (hypotonia, mental retardation and obesity, 15qll); Rubinstein Taybi syndrome (microcephaly, broad thumbs and big toes, dysmorphism and mental retardation; 16q13); and DiGeorge syndrome (congenital heart defect, hypoplasia of parathyroid and thymus, facial and palate anomalies; 22qll).

  • Genomic imprinting - Prader-Willi syndrome (microdeletion on paternal side or inheritance of both copies from maternal side) and Angelman syndrome (microdeletion on maternal side or inheritance of both copies from paternal side).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 3023-24

questions.text: A premature baby, born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1500 grams has stable vitals. What is the initial feeding method of choice?  (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube / Alternative oral route

 

Explanation:

 

For a premature baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with stable vitals, the preferred initial feeding method is oral feeding by spoon, paladai, or cup. If the baby cannot take an adequate amount of feeding by these methods, orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding should be initiated. This approach ensures that the baby receives sufficient nutrition while accommodating their developmental feeding abilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids: Typically used for extremely premature infants or those unable to tolerate enteral feeding.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids and oral feeding: This combination may be used in specific cases but is not the first choice for stable preterm infants at 33 weeks.

 

Option D. Total parenteral nutrition: Generally reserved for infants who cannot tolerate enteral feeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable preterm infants born at 33 weeks, the initial feeding method of choice is orogastric tube or alternative oral routes such as spoon, paladai, or cup feeding.

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition commonly seen in infants where there is hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to a narrowing of the pyloric canal. This condition presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding, typically around the age of 3 to 6 weeks. The physical finding of an "olive-shaped" mass in the abdomen is characteristic of this condition, which represents the enlarged pyloric muscle.

 

The X-ray findings in pyloric stenosis often show a single bubble sign due to gastric distension without further passage of air into the intestines. This is because the pyloric canal is obstructed, preventing stomach contents from moving into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: This term is more general and can refer to various types of obstructions within the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of an infant with projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass, this is not specific enough and does not pinpoint the pyloric obstruction characteristic of pyloric stenosis.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is characterized by a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, which is not present in this case. This condition leads to bilious vomiting due to a congenital closure or absence of the duodenal lumen, distinguishing it from pyloric stenosis, which presents with non-bilious vomiting.

 

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia would show a "triple bubble" sign on imaging, which indicates obstruction beyond the duodenum in the jejunum. This would also present with bilious vomiting, unlike the non-bilious vomiting seen in pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A mother with a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis is being counselled. She is concerned about the risk of transmitting the infection to her newborn through breastfeeding. The Pediatrician advises her on when it would be safe to resume breastfeeding after starting antitubercular therapy. For how many weeks should breastfeeding be avoided after initiating antitubercular therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Breastfeeding is generally contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis until they have been on antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period to minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant. The mother should avoid breastfeeding for the initial 2 weeks of treatment, as this is typically the period necessary for the mother to become non-infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommendations for breastfeeding in the context of maternal tuberculosis and antitubercular therapy. Mothers can often resume breastfeeding safely after the infectious period has passed, which is generally after the first 2 weeks of therapy.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.

 

Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood that has not been processed by the liver into its conjugated form. Gilbert syndrome is a common genetic disorder that causes mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition results from reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: (Mnemonic: DR BHATIA)

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This condition causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the liver's ability to secrete conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts, leading to its buildup in the liver.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome also leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign condition that results from a defect in the hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This condition also results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a serious liver disease in infants where the bile ducts become inflamed and blocked, preventing bile from draining from the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose


During neonatal resuscitation, suctioning is performed to clear the airway of the newborn to ensure effective breathing. The correct order for suctioning is mouth first, followed by the nose. This order is crucial because suctioning the nose first could cause the newborn to gasp and potentially aspirate any fluids or secretions present in the mouth.

 

Technical Details:

 

  • The suction catheter typically used is 12 or 14 French, and the suction pressure is maintained between 80-100 mmHg.
  • Tracheal suctioning has become obsolete and is no longer routinely performed unless specifically indicated.
  • Suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided as it can stimulate the vagal nerve, leading to apnea and/or bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose-mouth: This is incorrect as suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration.

 

Option C. Mouth-nose-oesophagus: Suctioning the esophagus is not part of the standard procedure and can cause complications such as vagal stimulation.

 

Option D. Trachea-nose-mouth: Tracheal suctioning is obsolete and not recommended in modern neonatal resuscitation protocols.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

 

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause several conditions, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash in children. It can also affect red blood cells, leading to pure red cell aplasia and aplastic crisis, especially in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders. In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis, a serious condition characterized by severe fetal anemia and fluid accumulation. However, petechial rash is not typically associated with parvovirus B19 infection. Petechial rashes are more commonly linked to other viral infections or conditions that cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia: Parvovirus B19 can infect erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying hematologic disorders.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, making this a well-documented complication.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: In individuals with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as sickle cell disease, parvovirus B19 infection can precipitate an aplastic crisis by temporarily halting red blood cell production in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

choices.text: It is a benign, self-limited transient condition
May result from a defect in migration of neural crest
May be associated with Hurler syndrome

questions.text:
A 32-year-old mother brings her 2-week-old neonate to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The neonate was delivered at term without any complications. The mother reports noticing multiple violet-black macules on the neonate's back and thigh since birth. The mother denies any family history of genetic disorders and states that the pregnancy was uneventful. On examination, the macules are well-demarcated, non-blanching, and do not appear to cause any discomfort to the neonate. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

 

 

Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the condition observed in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malignant degeneration in 1% cases

 

Option D: 

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical feature given is the Mongolian spots.

 

  • They are a self-limited neural crest migration defect and occur in normal neonates, slowly fading with age. (option A)

  • They are caused by the entrapment of melanocytes in the dermal layer during their migration from the neural crest to the epidermis in fetal development. (Option B)

  • Extensive spots may occur in Hurler syndrome. (Option C)

  • They do not require any therapy.

  • There is no any chance of malignant degeneration.

 

Other benign, transient neonatal changes seen are:

 

  • Transient neonatal pustular melanosis

  • Erythema toxicum

  • Breast enlargement

  • Vaginal discharge

  • Vernix caseosa

  • Caput succedaneum

  • Epstein pearls

  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages

 

Educational Objective

 

Mongolian spots/ congenital dermal melanocytosis - These spots are common, especially in individuals of Asian, African, and Latino descent, and are characterized by blue-gray to blue-black macules, typically located on the lumbosacral area. These spots occur due to ectopic melanocytes in dermis, disappear spontaneously by early childhood.

 

Note - Rarely Mongolian spots are associated with Hurler or Hunter syndromes, GM1 gangliosidosis, Niemann-Pick disease, mucolipidosis, and mannosidosis.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Page No- 13325

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

choices.text: Weight for height of the child.
Weight for age of the child.

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a concerned mother presents with her baby, Anu, who hails from a region currently experiencing severe drought conditions. Upon examination, Anu appears severely malnourished, prompting an urgent need for nutritional assessment. To determine the extent of acute malnutrition in Anu, which of the following parameters would be most appropriate for evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight for height of the child.

 

Option B:

 

The most accurate parameter for assessing acute malnutrition is Weight for Height. This measurement reflects the current nutritional status and is used to identify wasting, which indicates acute malnutrition. It shows whether the child's weight is appropriate for their height, irrespective of their age, making it a critical indicator for immediate nutritional interventions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Height for Age: This parameter is used to assess stunting, which indicates chronic malnutrition. It reflects the long-term nutritional and health status of the child and is not the best indicator for acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for Age: This combines both acute and chronic aspects of malnutrition, making it less specific for acute malnutrition. It can indicate underweight status but doesn't distinguish between stunting (chronic malnutrition) and wasting (acute malnutrition).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute malnutrition is also known as wasting & the parameter affected is weight for height

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A child has presented with a birth defect as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Craniorachischisis with anencephaly


Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect that involves both the brain and spinal cord. It is a combination of anencephaly and spina bifida, where there is a failure of closure of the entire length of the neural tube, resulting in the absence of the brain (anencephaly) and an open spinal cord (rachischisis). The image provided shows the characteristic features of this condition, including the exposed brain and spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: Anencephaly is considered an anterior neuropore defect. During embryonic development, the neural tube forms, and this process involves the closure of two openings known as neuropores—one at the anterior (head) end and one at the posterior (tail) end. Anencephaly occurs when there is a failure of the closure of the anterior neuropore, leading to incomplete development of the brain and skull.

 

 

Option C. Spina bifida: Neural tube defect with the best prognosis is spina bifida.

 

Option D. Anencephaly with meningocele: Anencephaly with meningocele is a neural tube defect with the following image

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect involving both the brain and spinal cord, with the worst prognosis among neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta, in contrast, has the best prognosis among these conditions.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

 

Surgical correction of a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) primarily helps in relieving the symptoms of congestive heart failure, which often manifest as failure to thrive in infants. Infants with VSD may experience poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, irritability, and signs of respiratory distress such as tachypnea and labored breathing. These symptoms arise because the left-to-right shunt created by the VSD increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and congestive heart failure. Surgical intervention closes the defect, thereby normalizing blood flow and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure, allowing the infant to grow and thrive normally.

 

The key indications for VSD surgery include:

 

  • Large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension.
  • Qp ratio greater than 2:1 (indicating a significant left-to-right shunt).
  • Supracristal VSD, which carries a risk of aortic valve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is not typically associated with VSD. VSD primarily affects the heart and pulmonary circulation rather than directly causing changes in the acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias in infants are usually related to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions, but not directly to VSD. Surgical correction of VSD is aimed at correcting the structural defect, not managing arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Heart block: Heart block is a conduction issue in the heart and is not a feature directly caused by VSD. VSD surgery does not specifically address heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

 

In the case described above, the neonate had unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, but had normal liver enzymes, PT/INR, and albumin levels, and no hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Crigler-Najjar type 2. The fact that bilirubin levels dropped after treatment with phenobarbital further supports this diagnosis.

 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

 

  • Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- Physiologic (newborn), Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome, Hemolytic
  • Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of uridine diphosphate glucuronyltransferase (UDPGT) caused by polymorphism. It is more common, affecting 5-10%. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Like Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome is also characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It presents with a dark liver on gross examination due to the accumulation of pigment, which is not consistent with the findings described.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar type 1: This condition is more severe than type 2 and typically presents with extremely high levels of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to a high risk of kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not respond to phenobarbital treatment, unlike the neonate described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

 

The procedure depicted in the image is orogastric tube insertion. This involves placing a tube through the mouth (orally) and advancing it down into the stomach. Orogastric tubes are commonly used in pediatric patients for several purposes:

 

  • Enteral rehydration: In children with mild-to-moderate dehydration, an orogastric tube can be used to facilitate enteral rehydration, allowing for fluid administration directly into the stomach.
  • Nutritional support: For children who are severely ill or have significant dehydration, orogastric tubes can also be used for nutritional support by delivering necessary nutrients and medications directly to the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubation: Intubation involves placing a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway and is primarily used in situations where airway protection or mechanical ventilation is required. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. Nasogastric tube insertion: Nasogastric tube insertion is similar to orogastric tube insertion, but the tube is inserted through the nose instead of the mouth. While both procedures aim to reach the stomach, the entry point distinguishes them.

 

Option D. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Oropharyngeal airways are devices inserted into the mouth to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway, usually during anesthesia or in unconscious patients. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

Explanation:

 

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of viral meningoencephalitis in children. These viruses are a leading cause of viral infections affecting the central nervous system, particularly in children. They typically cause a range of symptoms from mild febrile illness to severe meningoencephalitis. While other viruses like mumps, arboviruses, and HSV can also cause meningoencephalitis, enteroviruses are the most frequently identified causative agents in pediatric cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mumps: While it can cause meningoencephalitis, it is less common than enterovirus.

 

Option B. Arbovirus: These viruses are important causes of epidemic encephalitis but are not the most common in children.

 

Option C. HSV: Herpes simplex virus is a significant cause of sporadic encephalitis but not the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.
